Todas las socias del grupo quieren mejorar sus negocios, para esto solicitan mayor capital para comprar insumos y materia prima, dependiendo del caso. Estn seguras que sus ventas aumentaran y podrn obtener ingresos suficientes para solventar a sus familias.
texts.en:
The Nueva Vida ["New Life"] association is part of the Panamericana group in the Bolivian city of El Alto. The association has worked with Pro-Mujer for seven years. Mostly married with an average of five children each, some of the members have been abandoned by their partners andhad to take sole charge of their families. That's what led them to seek out ways to make enough money to support their families.

Nueva Vida members have diverse businesses. Soledad, for example, videotapes social events; Ross has a store selling lubricants; some make different kinds of "masitas" (a local snack); and others earn livings making macrame products. All of the members want to improve their businesses so they're applying for additional funds to buy products for resale or supplies, as the case may be. They are confident that their sales will increase and they'll be able to earn large enough incomes to support their families.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy products for resale or supplies, as appropriate.

loan.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea Y., 44, is married and lives with five of her children in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about $2.50 a day. Besides farming, her husband also works digging wells. Chea Y. is seeking a $250 loan in order to purchase a cow-cart to transport goods for a profit.
(Chea Y., her husband and one of her children are pictured at home)

loan.use: To purchase cow-cart.

loan.name: Prum

texts.en: Prum H., 58, is married and lives with her three young children in the Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband is a village doctor making US$10 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Prum H. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$400 to purchase more medicines for her husband.

loan.use: To purchase more medicines.

loan.name: Mercedes

texts.es: La seora Mercedes es una persona responsable y trabajadora tiene su propio negocio de abarrotes desde hace tres aos y esta solicitando este crdito para invertir en mercanca para su negocio y obtener mas clientes ya que ella le quiere brindar a su familia un futuro mas estable.
texts.en:
Mercedes is a responsible and hard-working person. She has had her own grocery business for three years and is applying for this loan to buy merchandise for the business and bring in more customers. She hopes to be able to provide a more stable future for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy merchandise to resell.

loan.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas L., 42, is a widow and lives with three of her children in the Kampong Cham province in Cambodia.
Since 1998, she has made her living selling groceries from her home and raising pigs. Aided by two of her children who are employed as a laborer and a driver respectively, she earns around $5 a day.
Meas L. would like to take out a loan of $400 to add inventory to her grocery business and purchase feed for her pigs.

loan.use: To add inventory to her grocery business and purchase feed for her pigs.

loan.name: Luis Manuel

texts.es: El seor Luis es una persona muy honesta, trabajadora y responsable, el y su esposa la seora Lety tienen nueve aos trabajando da con da su negocio que lleva por nombre Sper L. porque saben que solo trabajando pueden salir adelante. Estn solicitando este crdito para realizar el pago de un proveedor de refrescos por la compra de un pedido grande y mediante esto ellos consideran obtener una mayor cantidad de clientes, logrando mayor nmero de ventas y un mejor futuro para ellos y su familia.
texts.en:
Luis is an honest, hard-working and responsible person. He and his wife, Lety, have operated their business called Super L. for nine years, working day in and day out because they know that hard work is the only way to get ahead.

They are applying for this loan in order to pay a wholesale provider of soft drinks for a large order which, in turn, will allow them to increase their customer base, their sales and ultimately lead to a better future for their family.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy products for resale.

loan.name: Keng

texts.en: Keng C. is a widow who lives with her child, elder mother, and niece in the Kampong Cham Province ofCambodia. She is a tailor who also raises pigs on a plot of land behind her house to earn a living paying her $6 a day. She would like to take out a loan for $900 to purchase more pigs and feed to grow her business.

loan.use: To purchase pigs and feed.

loan.name: Hoar

texts.en: Hoar S., 43, is married and lives with four of her children in the Kampong Cham province. Working a farm together with her husband, Pang Chheng Han, she typically makes US$2 each day. Her husband also operates a mototaxi when not farming, and is able to make an extra $4 each day. Her family is also supported by one of the children who work in a garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Hoar S. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$200 to purchase feed for her pigs.

loan.use: To purchase feed for her pigs.

loan.name: Saut's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan intended for three individuals who live in Vatkor Commune in Battambang Province, Cambodia:
Saut H., 47, buys vegetables from a farmer and sells them at the local market. She has been doing this since 2007, and currently earns approximately $2 a day. She is married with six children, all of whom are single. Her husband, Moeun Kong, 38, drives a motorcycle taxi. Saut is applying for a loan to purchase additional vegetables for resale. Saut serves as the lead borrower for this loan.
Moeun N., 51, is single and also makes a living selling vegetables. She requests a loan to enlarge her business.
Moeurn N., 42, sells porridge on the side of the road in her village. She is seeking a loan in order to buy more ingredients for her business.

loan.use: To purchase additional vegetables for resale

loan.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim P., 30, is a single man who earns his living driving a taxi. He is able to make $23 in revenue per day. He has been doing this work since 2003. Currently his car has broken down so he needs to take out a loan of $800 to fix it. His car is a long term sustainable investment and he hopes to raise his standard of living.

loan.use: To fix his taxi

loan.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok N., 30, is married and lives with one child and her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She stays at home doing housework and raises fish to earn a living and is able to make around $2 each day. Her husband is a local teacher, making $5 a day.

Sok N. would like to take out a loan of $600 to build a basin in which she can breed fish.

loan.use: Build basin to breed fish.

loan.name: Tuy

texts.en: Tuy T., 29, is married and lives with her two young children in the Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband, Ken Chanthy, pictured above, works in construction and operates a mototaxi making US$5 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have made this a problematic economic year for many Cambodians, Tuy T. included. In light of these economic challenges, she is asking for a loan of US$300 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to run a taxi business.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for use as a taxi

loan.name: Chhorn

texts.en:
Chhorn C. Sim, 21, is a true entrepreneur who has a business selling groceries from her home and she is able to make $4 each day. Her husband, Eng Srann, 22, operates a taxi business and normally makes $3 profit per day to help support the family. This couple has one child who is still too young to attend school.

Chhorn C. Sim would like to take out a loan of $1000 to add to her grocery inventory and to purchase a water pump to irrigate her farm.

loan.use: Increase grocery inventory and purchase water pump for crop irrigation

loan.name: Tha

texts.en:
A 28-year-old smiling woman, Tha N., is the mother of one child and works selling biscuits, fruits, and other provisions to the people in her area. With her business activity she can typically make an income of about $4 per day.

Her husband is self-employed as a taxi-driver and can make $10 per day of income, which is contributed to support his household.

Tha N. has recently applied for a loan from KIVA to add more types of products to satisfy her clients' needs and to increase her profit margin.

loan.use: To buy more types of products to meet her customers' growing demands

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loan.name: Ek

texts.en: Ek L., 52, lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband and four children. She works as a farmer, making US$1 a day, and is supported by her husband who has a business grinding rice husks, making US$3 a day. In light of these times of economic difficulties, Ek L. is asking for a loan of US$200 to purchase a cart that can produce sugar cane juice. She is an ambitious entrepreneur who one day hopes to set up a grocery store in front of her home for one of her children. She sees this loan as a way to increase her income and is confident that her business venture will be successful.

loan.use: To purchase a sugar cane cart.

loan.name: Ma

texts.en:
Ma S., 53, is married and lives with two children and her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work raising fish and have a business transporting people by boat. On average, this couple earns a combined income of around $2 a day. They also get support from two children who work at garment factories.
Ma S. would like to take out a loan of $200 to purchase feed for her fish.

loan.use: To purchase feed for her fish.

loan.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea L., 48, is a widowed farmer who lives with five children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She grows and sells bananas at the market and is able to make $3 each day. Two of her children are married and no longer stay at home.

Chea L. is asking for a loan of $500 to rent a banana farm from an individual grower in order to increase her income.

loan.use: To rent a banana farm.

loan.name: Muon's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan composed of three borrowers who all reside in Battambang Province. Mrs. Muon K., 28, is a vegetable seller who sells items such as cabbages, morning glories, and water-lilies in Psathmeiy Market. She lives with her husband and five children in the family home. Her husband, Mr. Korng Seila, 33, is a construction worker. Mrs. K. has applied for a loan both to enlarge her business and to replace an old motorcycle.

The other two borrowers in the group are:

Mrs. Voeun V., 25, who sells vegetables in the market. She has requested a loan to replace an old motorcycle to make her family's transportation easier.

Mrs. Yon DaraV., 32, makes a living selling perfume at the market. She needs a loan to buy perfume materials to store and re-sell.

loan.use: to enlarge her business and replace an old motorcycle

loan.name: San

texts.en:
San S., 63, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She runs a grocery store, making around US$6 each day, and her husband sells traditional medicine and makes about US$1.5 per day.

Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has become out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also played a factor in making the price of rice very high. San S. is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase more groceries to meet her clients' demands. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her familys standard of living.

loan.use: To increase her grocery inventory

loan.name: Doung

texts.en:
Doung V., 46, is married and lives with four of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers and make US$2 each day. The family is also supported by two of the children who work in the local garment factories.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have made it a difficult economic year for many Cambodians. In light of these challenging times, she is asking for a loan of US$400 to breed pigs for extra profit. She sees this new business as a good economic investment and will use it to increase her income and improve her standard of living.

loan.use: To breed pigs.

loan.name: Khorn

texts.en:
Khorn K., 25, is married and lives in the Kampong Cham province with her two young children. She works in a grocery store, making around US$2.5 each day, while her husband typically makes US$2.5 every day as a mechanic, fixing motorbikes.
Inflation has driven up prices all across Cambodia and many Cambodians have faced economic struggles. Khorn K. has approached CREDIT for a loan of US$300 to make a new investment. She will purchase a generator and other tools to operate a business charging batteries. She feels that this investment can increase her income and raise her standard of living. (Her husband is pictured.)

loan.use: To purchase generator and tools to charge batteries

loan.name: I Nengah Widana

texts.id: I Nengah Widana sudah menyelesaikan pinjaman tahap pertama. Pinjaman itu dipergunakan untuk membeli pupuk dan bibit jaging kwalitas unggul. Sekarang kebun jagungnya sudah selesai dipanen. Tanah seluas 1 hektar yang dimilikinya, semuanya ditanami dengan jagung. Dalam satu tahun, I Nengah Widana bisa memanen jagungnya sebanyak tiga kali. Sekali panen I Nengah Widana mendapat keuntungan sebesar Rp. 2.000.000.- setelah dikurangi seluruh biaya yang diperlukan untuk pengolahannya. Jadi selama 1 tahun I Nengah Widana mendapat keuntungan sebesar Rp. 6.000.000.- Semua keuntungan tersebut dipergunakan untuk biaya kehidupan setiap hari, menabung, memperbaiki rumah dan membayar pinjaman yang dimilikinya. I nengah Widana merasa sangat mersyukur dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya karena penghasilannya bisa meningkat sehingga ia bisa meningkatkan kesejahteraan keluarganya. Saat ini musim hujan sudah tiba dan I Nengah Widana berencana untuk mendapatkan pinjaman kembali dengan jumlah yang lebih banyak karena ia berencana untuk menyewa lahan untuk ditanami jagung sehingga keuntungannya bisa meningkat.
texts.en:
I Nengah Widana had already repaid the loan of the first phase. That loan was used to purchase fertilizer and corn seedlings of superior quality. Currently his cornfield has just been harvested. The 1-hectare plot of land he owned is entirely cultivated with corn. Within a year, I Nengah Widana is able to harvest 3 crops of corn. Each harvest I Nengah Widana generate income of Rp. 2.000.000.- (about USD200) after deducting all payments needed for cultivation of the crop. Therefore in a year I Nengah Widana generated income of Rp. 6.000.000.- (about USD600). The entire mentioned income is used to pay daily living expenses, savings, for home improvement and repay loan he possess. I Nengah Widana is very thankful with the loan he received as his perquisite continued to increase until his familys welfare improved. At the moment is the rainy season thus I Nengah Widana planned to procure another larger loan as he planned to lease land to cultivate corn thus increasing his income.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Lease land, fertilizer and superior quality corn seedlings (Menyewa lahan, pupuk dan bibit jagung kwalitas unggul)

loan.name: Brooms, Foods Group

texts.vi: Phm Th V, sinh nm 1957 (Ms:010105030041 ) tham gia vay vn mc 3.180.000 vn , ch hin ang sng cng m chng v c con gi ln lm. Ch l ngi nhit tnh, ci m v mi ngi yu mn. nhng ngi dn trong lng thng c ngh lm chi tre, ch l mt trong s h. Vi s tin vay c ch mua tre v lm nguyen liu lm chi. Thu nhp bnh qun ca gia nh ch khong 3.000.000 vn / thng . Ch l nhm trng nhm vay vn gm 7 thnh vin:(p/) Phm Th Hoa, sinh nm 1970 (Ms 010105030043), tham gia vay vn mc vay: 3.180.000 vn mua tre na v lm chi ti nh, thu nhp bnh qun ca gia nh ch khong 2.000.000 vn / thng Ch Th Lan, sinh nm 1958 (Ms010105030042 ), tham gia vay vn mc vay: 3.180.000 vn i ch thu gom chi nan em bn l, thu nhp bnh qun ca gia nh ch khong 2.500.000 vn / thng V Th Qu, sinh nm 1957 (Ms 010105030044), tham gia vay vn mc: 3.180.000 vn mua tre na v lm chi, thu nhp bnh qun ca gia nh ch khong: 2.000.000 vn / thng Ng Th Thanh, sinh nm 1953 (Ms 010105030045), tham gia vay vn mc 3.180.000 vn, ch vay vn v kinh doanh hng n sng, thu nhp bnh qun ca gia nh ch khong 1.500.000 vnd/ thng Hong Th Hng, sinh nm 1962 (Ms 010105030049), tham gia vay vn mc vay: 2.204.000 vnd kinh doanh bn hng gii kht, an chi, thu nhp bnh qun ca gia nh ch khong; 2.000.000 vnd/ thng
texts.en:
Mrs. P., born in 1957, joined the Fund with a loan of 3,180,000 VND. She is currently living with her mother-in-law and her own grown daughter. She is an honest, open person who everybody admires. The people in her village mostly do work making bamboo brooms, herself included. With the loan, she bought bamboo to use as feedstock for her brooms. Her family's average income is about 3,000,000 VND/month. She is the group leader, which includes 7 participants: Hoa Thi P., born in 1970, is borrowing 3,180,000 from the Fund to buy bamboo to make brooms at home. Her family's average income is around 2,000,000 VND/month. Lan Thi C., born in 1958, joined the Fund with a loan of 3,180,000 VND to buy brooms at the local market and resell them. The family's average income is around 2,500,000 VND/month. Que Thi V., born 1957, joined the Fund with a loan of 3,180,000 VND to buy bamboo to make brooms. The family's average income is about 2,000,000 VND/month. Mrs. Thanh Thi N., born in 1953, joined the Fund with a loan of 3,180,000 VND to use in running a breakfast business. The family's average income is around 1,500,000 VND/month. Mrs. Hong Thi Hoan, born in 1962, joined the Fund with an amount of 2,204,000 VND to do business selling beverages, weaving brooms. The family's average income is around 2,000,000 VND/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Manufacturing brooms, food stands

loan.name: I Komang Sujana

texts.id: Pada musim tanam tahun lalu, I Komang Sujana menekuni usahanya menjual pupuk dan anti hama kepada petani. Selama satu musim tersebut, I Komang Sujana memperoleh cukup keuntungan dan keuntungan itu dipergunakannya untuk memperbaiki rumahnya, khususnya bagian dapur yang belum selesai direnovasi dan sebagian lagi ditabung untuk biaya sekolah anaknya. Karena selama satu musim menekuni usaha berjualan pupuk, lahan miliknya sendiri hampir terbengkelai dan tidak terurus. Saat ini sedang musim hujan dan waktu yang tepat untuk bercocok tanam. I Komang Sujana segera mengambil inisiatif untuk kembali mengerjakan lahan miliknya sambil tetap berjualan pupuk. I Komang Sujana memerlukan dana untuk biaya pengolahan tanah, karena untuk mengolah lahan seluas 1,5 hektar miliknya, ia memerlukan tenaga kerja tambahan yang dibayar per hari sebesar Rp. 25.000.- Biasanya memerlukan waktu selama 5 hari untuk siap ditanami padi. Selain untuk biaya tenaga kerja, dana tersebut dipergunakan untuk membeli bibit padi kwalitas unggul karena I Komang Sujana mengharapkan hasil yang maksimal. Dengan masa panen selama 3 kali setahun, I Komang Sujana optimis usahanya bisa sukses dan segala usaha yang dilakukannya untuk mensejahterakan keluarganya.
texts.en:
In the previous years growing season, I Komang Sujana was diligent in his fertilizer and pesticide-selling venture. In the season mentioned, I Komang Sujana acquire adequate income and that income was used to improve his home, specifically the kitchen where the renovation is unfinished and the balance saved for the childrens education expenses. As during the season diligently selling fertilizer, his land is next to uncompleted and derelict. Currently the rainy season is appropriate and suitable time for planting. I Komang Sujana immediately take the initiative to resume working on his land while selling fertilizer. I Komang Sujana require funds to pay for the preparation of the land, as to cultivate the 1.5-hectare land he owned, required extra labor costing Rp. 25.000.- (about USD2.50) per day. Usually requiring a period of 5 days to complete planting with paddy. Besides paying for the labor, the mentioned funds are used to purchase superior quality paddy seedlings as I Komang Sujana hope for maximum yield. With 3 harvests per year, I Komang Sujana is optimistic his venture will be successful and all his effort expended to better the familys welfare.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Hire labor and purchase superior quality paddy seedlings (menyewa tenaga kerja dan membeli bibit padi kwalitas unggul)

loan.name: Phen

texts.en:
Mrs. Phen L., 76, is a widow and the mother of one daughter, aged 46, who works with her. Phen L. owns a grocery store at her home where they sell different types of grocery products and food provisions to the people in her area.

She and her daughter started this business in 2001 and can make an income of about $6 to $9 per day. To increase her profit margin, Phen L. is asking for a loan to expand her inventory by adding more products.

loan.use: To purchase more grocery products to expand her business.

location.town: Tboung Kmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambo

loan.name: Hong's Group

texts.en:
There are five borrowers in this group, all residing in Somroangknong Commune in Battambang Province. Mrs. Hong S., 25, owns and runs a small store at the local market selling vegetables. She earns money to sustain her family and pay school fees for her young child. She is married to Tha Chenda, 28, a motorcycle taxi driver. To increase their income and make progress in the business, Mrs. S. has applied for this loan to purchase different kinds of vegetables for sale.

Mrs. S. is the group leader and there are four other members:

Mrs. Ruom N., 54, a widow, is a fruit seller. She needs a loan to expand her business.

Mrs. Soeum S., 45, a vegetable seller, is asking for a loan to buy additional vegetables to sell.

Mrs. Han S., age 25, makes a living selling Khmer Cake. She requests a loan to purchase ingredients to make more cakes, and

Mrs. Chuon P., 43, sells vegetables and needs a loan to buy more vegetables for sale.

loan.use: to purchase different kinds of vegetables for re-sale

loan.name: Thi Huong

texts.vi: Ch Th Hng, sinh nm 1975(M s 010105030052),y l ln u tin ch tham gia vay vn ca t chc ti chnh vi m Bnh Minh. Ch tham gia vay mc 1.972.000 vn mua tre v an chi. Chng ch hng ngy i lm thu c thu nhp theo ngy, thu nhp bnh qun ca gia nh ch khong 2.500.000 vn/ thng. c ch em gii thiu, ch cng vay vi cc ch em trong nhm vay c 7 ngi. c vay vn ch rt vui v mong mun c tham gia lu di nh cc ch em khc trong thn v ha s hon tr vn vay y .
texts.en:
Mrs. Huong Thi D. was born in 1975. This is her first time participating in the Binh Minh fund. She joined with a loan of 1,972,000 VND to buy bamboo to weave brooms. Her husband works as labor for hire every day and gets paid daily. Her family's average income is 2,500,000 VND per month. She was introduced to the fund by her sisters and she is participating in a group loan of 7 people. She is very glad to be able to borrow from this fund and hopes to be a long time participant like her sisters in the town. She promises to repay the loan in full.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy bamboo

loan.name: I Gede Gama

texts.id: I Gede Gama memiliki lahan seluas 1 hektar. Seluruh lahan yang dimilikinya ditanami padi, karena pengairan didaerahnya cukup memadai sepanjang tahun. Namun, selama masa tanam 1 tahun, lahan tersebut ditanami secara bergantian antara padi, jagung dan kedelai. Hal itu dilakukan untuk mempertahankan kesuburan tanah dan hal itu tergantung pada cuaca. Saat ini sedang musim hujan, musim yang tepat untuk menanam padi. Untuk mengolah lahan seluas itu, I Gede Gama memerlukan tambahan dana untuk meningkatkan hasil yang ingin didapatnya. Sebelumnya ia hanya mengandalkan bibit padi biasa sehingga hasil yang didapatnya tidak maksimal karena padinya mudah terserang penyakit. Selain untuk membeli bibit kwalitas unggul, pinjaman tersebut dipergunakan untuk menyewa tenaga kerja saat pengolahan tanah dan membeli anti hama. Menggunakan bibit unggul adalah hal yang pertama kali bagi I Gede Gama dan ia yakin usahanya akan sukses sehingga ia bisa meningkatkan pendapatannya untuk kesejahteraan keluarganya.
texts.en:
I Gede Gama owned a 1-hectare land. The entire land owned is planted with paddy, as there is adequate irrigation all year round in the area. Thus in the growing period of a year, the mentioned land can be planted on a rotational basis with paddy, corn and soy. This rotational planting is to preserve richness of the land and also dependent on the weather. Currently the rainy season, the appropriate season for planting paddy. For cultivating the land of this size, I Gede Gama required additional funds to increase the expected yield. Previously he only rely on the regular paddy seedlings so resulting in less than maximum yield as paddy is easily infested by disease. Apart from purchasing superior quality paddy seedlings, the mentioned loan will also be used to hire labor during the cultivating period and purchase pesticide. This is the first time I Gede Gama is using superior seedlings and he is assured his effort will be successful so increases his income for the familys welfare.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase superior quality paddy seedlings, pesticide and hire labor (Membeli bibit padi kwalitas unggul, anti hama dan menyewa tenaga kerja)

loan.name: Khuon's Group

texts.en:
This is a group made up of three members. Mrs. Khuon S., 36, sells vegetables, ordering them from a wholesale supplier or a farmer, to sell retail in Psatmeiy Market. She has two young children; both live at home and go to school. Khuon S. is married to Vorn Veuy, 35, who works in construction. Mrs. S. hopes to expand her business so she would like to request a loan to buy more kinds of vegetables to sell.

Mrs. S.'s group has two other members:

Mrs. Oeurp O., 27, who is working for a small firm as a cleaner. To earn more income, she is applying for a loan to purchase vegetables for sale.

Mrs. Im P., 46, is a cleaner who works for a company. She is requesting a loan to buy chickens for her husband to sell. They all live in Battambang Province.

loan.use: to buy more kinds of vegetables for re-sale

loan.name: I Gede Widiarsana

texts.id: I Gede Widiarsana memiliki lahan seluas 1 hektar. Seluruh lahan yang dimilikinya ditanami dengan padi, karena pengairan yang cukup memadai sepanjang tahun. Selama 1 tahun, tanaman padi bisa dipanen sebanyak 3 kali. Sebelumnya, I Gede Widiarsana menanam padi dengan bibit jenis lokal karena harganya yang lebih murah. Namun, keuntungan yang didapatnya tidak maksimal, karena bibit jenis lokal mudah terserang penyakit. Dalam satu kali panen ( 4 bulan ), ia hanya mendapat keuntungan sebesar Rp. 500.000.- setelah dikurangi semua biaya untuk pengolahan tanah dan perawatan tanaman. Hal itu dirasakan belum mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya, apalagi dengan kondisi ekonomi saat ini. Karena ingin meningkatkan taraf hidupnya dan keluarganya, I Gede Widiarsana mengajukan pinjaman ke Yayasan Dinari sebesar Rp. 6.000.000.- Pinjaman tersebut dipergunakan untuk membeli bibit padi kwalitas unggul sebesar Rp. 3.000.000.-, biaya pengolahan tanah dengan menyewa pekerja sebesar Rp. 1.000.000.- dan membeli pupuk serta anti hama sebesar Rp. 2.000.000.- I Gede Widiarsana sudah belajar dengan petani yang sudah lebih dulu menggunakan bibit kwalitas unggul sehingga ia tidak ragu untuk mendapat pinjaman, karena sesuai dengan kenyataan, bibit padi kwalitas unggul mampu menghasilkan hingga 3 kali lipat dibanding dengan bibit jenis lokal. Satu kali panen, bibit unggul bisa mendapatkan keuntungan sebesar Rp. 1.500.000.- hingga Rp. 2.000.000.- I Gede Widiarsana yakin usaha akan sukses, apalagi dengan terus didampingi oleh staf Dinari dan petani padi yang telah sukses dengan bibit padi kwalitas unggul.
texts.en:
I Gede Widiarsana owned a 1-hectare land. The entire land owned is planted with paddy, as irrigation is available throughout the year. During the year, growing paddy is usually harvested 3 times. Before this, I Gede Widiarsana plant paddy using the local seedlings as they are less expensive. Thus the income generate is less than maximum, as the local seedlings is easily infested by disease. In each growing season of 4 months, he only generated income of Rp. 500.000.- (about USD50) after deducting all payments for cultivating and maintenance expenses. This is insufficient to cover the familys expenses, especially with the current economic condition. With the intention of improving the standard of his and familys life, I Gede Widiarsana proposed a loan from Dinari Foundation for Rp. 6.000.000.- (about USD600). This mentioned loan would be used to purchase superior quality paddy seedlings costing Rp. 3.000.000.-, pay for cultivating the land and hiring labor costing Rp. 1.000.000.-, and purchase fertilizer and pesticide costing Rp. 2.000.000.-. I Gede Widiarsana already studied with farmers who have been using superior quality seedlings until he does not doubt getting a loan, as in reality, superior quality paddy seedlings is able to yield up to 3 times compared to local seedlings. Each harvest, superior seedlings is able to generate income of between Rp. 1.500.000.- and Rp. 2.000.000.- I Gede Widiarsana is confident his effort will be successful, also with supported by Dinaris staff and paddy farmers who have succeeded with superior quality paddy seedlings.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Superior quality paddy seedlings, fertilizer, pesticide and hire labor (Bibit padi kwalitas unggul, pupuk, anti hama dan menyewa pekerja)

loan.name: Mabelle

texts.en:
Mrs. Mabelle L. is a young wife and mother of 2 from Unidos, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 22 years old and decided to put up a little business retailing cosmetics from which to earn a meager income. She started the business by applying for a loan from Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative. She describes the hardships of living as a young couple. They have a motocycle for another source of income. Her husband drives it daily as a motor taxi. They work hard to support the family.

At present, the family business needs working capital. They would like to purchase additional stocks of cosmetics. They feel that their retailing business is doing well. They approached Paglaum MPC for Mabelle's 2nd loan of PHP 10,000. They hope to stretch their income out from cosmetics retailing as they need money for motorcycle repair. Moreover, Mabelle's husband has to renew his driver's license. They know that if one of them stops working, the family will suffer.

Sometime in the future, Mabelle wants to own additional motorcycles and wishes to become a cosmetics wholesaler one day. She smiles at the thought of seeing their children finish their studies.

loan.use: to purchase additional stocks of cosmetics

loan.name: I Ketut Jiwa

texts.id: I Ketut Jiwa tinggal didesa Manistutu, Bali Barat. Lokasi desa ini berada di lereng gunung, sehingga untuk pengairan, baik untuk perkebunan atau untuk kepentingan rumah tangga cukup sulit untuk didapat. Pengairan hanya mengandalkan sungai kecil yang mengalir didesanya yang airnya akan cukup apabila datang musim hujan. Karena air yang sulit didapat, I Ketut Jiwa tidak bisa bercocok tanam atau mengolah persawahan. I Jiwa menanami kebunnya dengan pohon jagung. Namun karena kurangnya pupuk dan bibit yang berkwalitas, I Ketut Jiwa seringkali tidak mendapat hasil yang maksimal dari kebunnya. Dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya, I Ketut Jiwa berencana untuk membeli pupuk dan bibit jagung berkwalitas sehingga kebunnya bisa mendapatkan hasil yang maksimal.
texts.en:
I Ketut Jiwa live in the village of Manistutu, West Bali. This village is located on a hillside, so for irrigation, sufficient for plantation or for household is difficult to be adequate. Irrigation is only dependant on the small stream flowing through the village where the water is only sufficient during the rainy season. Due to the insufficient water supply, I Ketut Jiwa cannot grow plant or cultivate rice. I Ketut Jiwa plant his farm with corn. And with inadequate fertilizer and quality seedlings, I Ketut Jiwa often did generate maximum yield from his plantation. With this loan received, I Ketut Jiwa planned to purchase fertilizer and quality corn seedlings so that his plantation generate maximum yield.

Translated from Indonesian by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Corn seedlings, fertilizer and pesticide (Bibit jagung, pupuk dan anti hama)

loan.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
For 20 years, Erlinda T. has been in the fish-selling business. She is 50 years old, the mother of 6, and mounted their humble home in Clarin, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. Her husband has been supporting the family as a driver using their own motor taxi for more than a decade.

Erlinda shares that she has to be wise with her time. Before selling fish around the little "barangay" (neighborhood), she makes sure to feed a number of pigs in their backyard. She never minds the hard work. She knows that sacrifices bear good fruit. She says she has to earn 6 times for her 6 children.

She thought of investing more in "banyeras" (deep containers of fish) and trying selling fruits. She applied for PHP 15,000 loan from Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative. She is at peace with Paglaum's help in providing capital.

Mrs. T., happily shares that her greatest dream is for her children to have a good life. And that she and her husband will retire and have a decent home.

loan.use: Invest in additional "banyeras" of fish and capital for fruit selling

loan.name: I Ketut Keder

texts.id: I Ketut Keder memiliki lahan seluas 1,5 hektar. Seluruh lahan yang dimilikinya ditanami dengan padi, karena pengairan yang cukup memadai sepanjang tahun. Selama 1 tahun, tanaman padi bisa dipanen sebanyak 3 kali. Sebelumnya, I Ketut Keder menanam padi dengan bibit jenis lokal karena harganya yang lebih murah. Namun, keuntungan yang didapatnya tidak maksimal, karena bibit jenis lokal mudah terserang penyakit. Dalam satu kali panen ( 4 bulan ), ia hanya mendapat keuntungan sebesar Rp. 500.000.- setelah dikurangi semua biaya untuk pengolahan tanah dan perawatan tanaman. Hal itu dirasakan belum mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya, apalagi dengan kondisi ekonomi saat ini. Karena ingin meningkatkan taraf hidupnya dan keluarganya, I Ketut Keder mengajukan pinjaman ke Yayasan Dinari sebesar Rp. 6.000.000.- Pinjaman tersebut dipergunakan untuk membeli bibit padi kwalitas unggul sebesar Rp. 3.000.000.-, biaya pengolahan tanah dengan menyewa pekerja sebesar Rp. 1.000.000.- dan membeli pupuk serta anti hama sebesar Rp. 2.000.000.- I Ketut Keder sudah belajar dengan petani yang sudah lebih dulu menggunakan bibit kwalitas unggul sehingga ia tidak ragu untuk mendapat pinjaman, karena sesuai dengan kenyataan, bibit padi kwalitas unggul mampu menghasilkan hingga 3 kali lipat dibanding dengan bibit jenis lokal. Satu kali panen, bibit unggul bisa mendapatkan keuntungan sebesar Rp. 1.500.000.- hingga Rp. 2.000.000.- Dengan terus didampingi oleh staf Dinari dan petani padi yang telah sukses dengan bibit padi kwalitas unggul, I Ketut Keder optimis yakin ushanya kan sukses.
texts.en:
I Ketut Keder owns a land of 1.5 hectares (around 3.7 acres). Due to his land does not have a proper irrigation system, he uses his whole land for paddy farming. He can harvests his paddy farming 3 times a year. He used local paddy seeds in the past because they were cheaper. However he was not able to get a good result out of it. In one harvest season (around 4 month period) he can only get a profit of IDR 500 thousand (around USD 45). That was certainly not enough to make a living especially in this current economic condition.

I Ketut Keder wants to improve his family welfare and therefore he applied for a loan from Dinari foundation for an amount of IDR 6 million (around USD 550). He used IDR 3 million (USD 275) to buy high quality paddy seeds, another IDR 1 million (USD 92) was spent for hiring some men to clear and work the land, and IDR 2 million (USD 183) to buy fertilizer and pesticide.

I Ketut Keder has learned from senior farmers in farming with high quality seeds, hence he is confidence he can succeed this time. He can triple his revenue using this quality seeds, so instead of having a profit of UD 45 per harvest seasons, he can earn up to USD 135 - USD 180/ harvest season. In addition he also gets a continuous support and guidance from Dinari foundation's field instructor so he is even more confidence that he will succeed this time.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy high quality paddy seeds, fertilizer and pesticide B

loan.name: Theresia

texts.en:
Born in 1960, Mama B. (Theresia) was married but her husband died some ten years ago. Before his death they had five children. Unable to care for the family single-handedly and needing capital to expand her business (sale of cooked food), she joined GHAPE in 2003. Shes been having a lot of problems with her late husbands brothers, and this made her sad all the time but she is appreciative of the fact that she is alive. Her desire is to give her children love and education.

Mama B. states that she feels better each time she provides something small for her children. Her inability to get investment capital which could constantly generate income for her to meet her childrens needs is what motivated her to obtain a loan from GHAPE. With her previous loan of US$ 600, she succeeded in running a restaurant that provided her community with good food.

Given a loan, she plans to buy a two-wheeled motorcycle, koki beans, and palm oil. She knows this business will succeed because she is located at a good business site and she has a good rider for the motorcycle. She plans to use the profits generated to pay for her children's schooling and to cater for the basic needs of her family.

She plans to repay her loan in 24 months. The first installment of the repayment shall be due on the fourth month after the loan disbursement.

loan.use: Purchase of a two-wheeled motorcycle, koki beans, and palm oil

loan.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary A. is 48 years old and is married to a local businessman. They have four children, one in school and the other three in college. Rosemary and her husband also support one of their grandchildren.

Rosemary owns a hardware store in Rongo, Kenya where she sells cement, paint, nails, and iron sheets, among other items. Rosemary has been running the business since 2002, and is now applying for a loan of 40,000 Kenya Schillings in order to increase her stock.

loan.use: Purchasing cement, paint, and iron sheets

loan.name: Zinunula Women's Group1

texts.en:
Margaret K. is one of the executive members of Zinunula Womens Group 1 in Mityana. She has a tailoring business that she has been running for over 10 years. Margaret, 42, is married with 6 children, of whom 4 are still in school while the eldest 2 are managing their own businesses.

Margaret is lucky in that she runs her business from her home and she makes shirts, skirts, trousers. In running her business, Margaret buys materials from Mityana and at times from Kampala and the clothes she makes are sold within Mityana town and out of her home since most people know her as an expert at what she does. Margaret needs a loan to be able to buy more material for her business.

loan.use: buy more fabric for her business

loan.name: Chek

texts.en:
Chek K. is 37 years old and sells fruit in Battambong province. Her business has been around for about five years and she makes US$ 2.50 every day, while her husband is a teacher and makes US$ 2.50 as well to help support the family.

Selling fruit has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions that have not been conducive to a good growing season. Chek K. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to make two investments. She would like to invest US$ 500 to create another business selling beef and pork and also put US$ 500 into her own fruit business, increasing her stock of fruits to sell. She sees these investments as opportunities that will help her to increase her daily income.

loan.use: To operate a new business and add more fruits

loan.name: Khan

texts.en:
Mrs. Khan C., 25, is married and lives with her husband and one child in Bathambong Province, Cambodia. She started a grocery business in 2006. She usually buys wholesale grocery products from a market in her town and starts re-selling them to the people in her community. From her activity, she can typically make on average US$ 3/day in income.

Meanwhile, her husband is employed by a private company as a driver, making US$ 150 per month. For her household expenses, Mrs. C. spends on average US$ 50 on food, US$ 15 on utilities, and US$ 15 on her business transportation.

Presently, Mrs. C. is asking for a loan to keep expanding her inventory to meet her customer demand.

loan.use: To buy more products to expand her inventory

loan.name: Mrs. Korn Chuon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank consists of ten people who all live in Trapang Pring Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Korn C. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a cow breeder. She is a 51-year-old widow with four children, two of whom are firewood collectors who usually go into the forest and gather firewood to sell, while the other two are attending the local school.
Although she and her children have different businesses, they still live in an old house and poor conditions. In order to provide better conditions, Mrs. Korn C. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family.
This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Two members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These two are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMKs main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodias poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMKs clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To add to her savings to build a new house for her family.

loan.name: Zinunula Group2

texts.en: Isa M. is 27 years old and is a member of the Zinunula group in Mityana. He is a businessman with a butcher shop in Mityana town that he has been operating for one and a half years. Prior to this business, he had a business of roasting chicken, but due to the increased price of buying chicken, he changed and now he is happy with his butcher shop. Since the festive season is around the corner, Isa needs a loan to buy more meat for his shop in order to fetch more profits. Isa is not married, but he has a child and pays school fees plus upkeep for this child, while also taking care of his mother in the village. He works alone in the butcher shop and he has a dream that with the accumulated profits, he will one day buy a plot of land and build a house.

loan.use: To buy more meat for his butcher shop.

loan.name: Mrs. Choeurn Thorn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Ten people in Tranpaing Pring Village in Kampong Chhnang Province form a village bank loan, and Mrs. Choeurn T. is the village bank president.
She is a grocer who owns a store in the local market. Since she has a lot of customers with many demands, she wants to expand her business. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery goods for her customers. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan.
Her husband, Mr. Nath Kar, sells firewood. Mrs. Choeurn T. is a 28-year-old mother of two children who are too young to work or study.
This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Three members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These three members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMKs main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodias poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMKs clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To buy more grocery goods for her customers.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase piglets, palm oil and operate a restaurant

loan.name: Svay

texts.en:
Svay P. S., 18, is single and is part of a poor farming family in Bathambong province, Cambodia. When he was 16, he decided to drop out of school because his family didnt have enough money to support him, and he was committed to generating additional income to supplement his family's income.
In 2007, he started a business as a motor-taxi driver. Now he is able to generate on average around $2.50 per day of income. Svay P. has recently requested a loan to fix his motor-bike to make it more comfortable for his customers. (He is pictured with his client).

loan.use: To fix his motor-bike to make his clients more comfortable

loan.name: Agali Awamu Tukole Group1

texts.en: Nathan K. is the chairperson of Agali awamu Tukole group in Mityana. He has a business of selling produce such as beans, maize, and maize flour, ground nuts and many other products. He has had this business for 1 year now. When he had just joined his lending group, he was selling clothes in the daily markets around Mityana and Mubende, but because of his age he changed businesses. He buys the produce from farmers all around at a favourable price for him and then sells it both retail and wholesale from his store in Mityana town. Nathan is married with 10 children, 3 of whom are in school, ane he also cares for 1 grandchild. The profits he makes help him so much with paying school fees, as well as caring for his family, and paying rent for his store premises. Nathan needs a loan to be able to buy more produce for sale.

loan.use: To buy more produce for sale.

loan.name: Ny's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Ny N. is a group leader of four members who all live in Ta Krong village in Kampong Chhnang province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice.
Aside from this plantation, he is a firewood seller. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy more firewood to re-sell. He hopes to increase his income and provide a better life for his family.
His wife, Mrs. Nil Sary, is a pig breeder. Mr. Ny N. is 37-years-old and the father of three children, one of whom helps their father with his business while the other three are attending the local school.

loan.use: To buy more firewood to re-sell.

loan.name: Chantha's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Chantha D. is a group leader of six members who all live in Trabek village in Kampong Chhnang province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.
Aside from this plantation, he is a fish seller in the local market. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to add to his savings to buy more fish to re-sell. He hopes to increase his income and improve his living conditions with this loan.
His wife, Mrs. Meas Chakriya, is a pig breeder. Mr.Chantha D. is 23-years-old, and he does not have a child yet.
This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These four members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMKs main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodias poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMKs clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To add his savings to buy more fish to re-sell.

loan.name: Agali Awamu Tukole Group2

texts.en: Rose S. is one of the executive members of Agali Awamu Tukole group in Mityana. She is a farmer and has owned her bean, cassava, maize and matooke plantations for a very long time. When the produce is ready, she sells to her customers from her home and the market at a favorable price. As a result of getting loans, she has been able to buy furniture for her home, keep her kids in school and buy animals like cows and goats for milk and meat. Rose needs a loan to buy produce from other farmers to supply her regular customers.

loan.use: To buy more produce from other farmers

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: To buy cloth to make clothes for her customers.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase more piglets and pig food for her breeding.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To add to her savings to purchase more fruits for her husband's business.

loan.name: Nasuuti Women's Group

texts.en: N. Fatumah is 35 years of age and the chairperson of Nasuuti womens group, a new group in Mukono. She is married with 4 children. One of her children has just finished her Senior 4 leaving examinations; one is in Senior 3, another is in her Primary 7 vacation, and the last-born is in Primary 4. Fatumah cares for her mother and two brothers-in-law. She has a restaurant business called Bismillah Restaurant which she has been running for 2 years, and she is happy that her good services and customer care has enabled her to keep a good clientele. In her business, she is helped by her family members while her husband does other businesses. She prepares breakfast, lunch and supper with very nice meals bringing out the aroma all over the place. This is her first loan with Pearl Microfinance and she has planned to buy and stock food stuffs for her restaurant.

loan.use: To buy and stock food stuffs for her restaurant.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To buy more rice to re-sell.

loan.name: Vann

texts.en:
Mrs. Vann M. lives in Tie Buon village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Sok Nim, is a bamboo seller.
Even though they have different businesses, they still earn less income than is needed to support their household, so they want to expand their businesses. Thus, Mrs. Vann M. decided to ask for a loan to purchase more bamboo, piglets, and pig food for her business. She hopes to increase her income and provide a better life for her family.
She is 38 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is attending the local school, while the others are too young to work or study because they are at the ages of one month and two years old.

loan.use: To purchase more bamboo, piglets, and pig food for her business.

loan.name: Nhm 06- ng Thnh Group

texts.en:
Loan Group 6 consists of five poor women, all of whom have market stalls opposite Hng c University in Thanh Ho City. Thanh Ho City is the provincial capital of Thanh Ho province, one of the poorest provinces in Vit Nam. It is located approximately 150 kilometers south of H Ni, the capital of Vit Nam.

Mrs. i is the lead borrower of the group. She is 39 years old, married, and has two children. Her eldest child is a student and her 18-year-old child works as a tailor.

As with her previous three loans, all of which have been repaid on time and in full, Mrs. i will use her share of the loan to buy various types of rice which she then sells from her market stall located across the street from Hng c University. Mrs. i will use the profits from the loan to pay school fees and to reinvest in her business.

The loan will be split equally between all five borrowers. The other borrowers in the group will use their share of the loan for similar purposes:

Mrs. N is borrowing 3,079,800 Vietnamese Dong (~US$181) to buy shoes, handbags and other accessories that she will sell from her market stall.

Both Mrs. Loan and Mrs. Tuyt will use their shares of the loan to purchase a range of small household goods (such as cookies, milk, towels, skin care products, etc.) that they will sell from their market stalls.

Mrs. Hng is borrowing to buy fruit (such as apples, oranges and bananas) that she will resell in Thanh Ho City and in her village.

loan.use: Buy food, rice, fruit and general household goods

loan.name: Suor's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Suor C. is a group leader of six people who all live in Tro Ngel village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a grocer who owns a small store in the local market.
She now wants to expand her business and improve her family's living conditions. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to purchase grocery goods.
Her husband, Mr. Ouk Sanh, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. Mrs. Suor C. is 51 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is a farmer while the others are attending the local school.
This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These five members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMKs main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodias poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMKs clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To add to her savings to purchase grocery goods.

loan.name: Mavzunahon

texts.en:
Mavzunahon A. lives in Khujand. She is a loving mother of 3 pretty children. Despite the fact that she raises her children alone, she is full of enthusiasm and readiness to work hard to ensure a good future for her children. Mavzunahon is engaged in commercial service and trade. She trades an assortment of children's wear in the local bazaar. For example, she trades the seasonal wear for teenagers (jackets, sports wear and warm socks).
She is an active client of MicroInvest, and she has worked closely with the program since 2005. She is a reliable client who trusts the MicroInvest's loan procedure. Mrs. Mavzunahon A. is applying to KIVA for a loan to import seasonal wear and increase her business turnover. She thanks KIVA for its support and wishes all the best.

loan.use: To import seasonal children's wear and increase business turnover

loan.name: Sakhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sakhorn L. lives in Lvea Sor Kandal village in Kandal province. She is a cabbage seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Huot Chhuon, is a construction worker.
Even though they try to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to provide a better life for their family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sakhorn L. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy timbers to build a house for her family to live in better conditions.
She is 38 years old and the mother of seven children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another four are enrolled in the local school, and the remaining two are too young to work or study because they are at the ages of one and four years old. Her husband is also presented with her in the picture.

loan.use: To add to her savings to buy timbers to build a house for her family to live in better conditions.

loan.name: Sao

texts.en: Mrs. Sao R., age 59, runs a rice store in her home. She purchases rice from a farmer and resells it to her customers for profit, and has been in this business since 1998. She takes care of five children, four of whom are students and one is a farmer. Her husband, Mr. Nob Ra, 42, is a rice farmer. She has applied for a loan to increase the amount of rice in her store, and to buy a secondhand motorcycle and a bicycle to make transportation easier for her family. They all reside in Pursat Province.

loan.use: To buy more rice, a secondhand motorcycle, and a bicycle.

loan.name: Thoeurn

texts.en:
Mr. Thoeurn T. lives in Kradas Khor village in Kampong Cham province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.
On the plantation, he faces an obstacle because his field has infertile soil which has a bad effect on his crop. In order to solve this problem, Mr. Thoeurn T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field and make his crop more productive.
He is a 58-year-old widower with two children, one of whom is a palm juice collector, while the other is a farmer who helps their father on the plantation.

loan.use: To buy fertilizer to support the field and make his crop more productive.

loan.name: Moise

texts.en:
Alid means another path always exists for the most poor in Fon, the principal tribal language of Cotonou, Benin. Benin is a small country in West Africa sandwiched between Togo and Nigeria. GDP per capita stands at $1,500 and poverty is endemic to the capital city of Cotonou. Alid operates seven different locations in and around Cotonou to ensure that those who need help can help themselves through small loans.

Moise D. is a smiling man with five children, ages 8, 11, 14, 17, and 21. Moise is married to Madeleine Kpadonou. Three of his children have been to school while two work as fishermen. Moise lives in a small house by the lake in Cotonou, Benin.

Eleven years ago Moise was a fisherman, as most are here, but due to a stomach and lung ailment he was forced to quit. With Alids help, he has started a business that complements a fishermans life he sells nets to catch fish and logs to construct houses along the edge of the lake. Despite the obvious difficulties of his business he remains cheerful.

Moise would like to build a guesthouse to rent out when he is older and unable to continue his current business. This is Moises fifth loan to buy more supplies. Moise is the leader of a group of Alid lenders who are also fishermen on the lake.

loan.use: Purchase of nets and logs

loan.name: Matluba

texts.en: Matluba A. has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2003. She first applied when she decided to increase her existing business. Thanks to the previous loans, she was able to increase business turnover and open a cosmetics business. Mrs. A. works directly with the suppliers, so she can sell at lower prices and therefore have repeat customers. She has a good assortment (creams, shampoo, soaps, toilet water, perfume, etc). Mrs. A. is requesting a business development loan to improve her business.

loan.use: To improve her business

loan.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. Ny S. is a farmer and lives in Phdau Chum Koeut village in Kampong Cham province. She owns 1-hectare of land to cultivate rice.
On this plantation, she can earn a little rice revenue to provide a better life for her family. In order to improve her living conditions, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase five piglets to start a pig breeding business, and pig food for her breeding.
Mrs. Ny S. is 33-years-old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school.

loan.use: To purchase five piglets to start a pig breeding business, and pig food for her breeding.

loan.name: Akumcha

texts.en:
M. was born in 1963, and is happily married with 6 children, among whom one is less than 15 years old. Life was so miserable for her when she became an orphan. Because of this M. thought her own life had come to an end without the presence of her parents. In the year 2004, she came to know of GHAPE, became a member, and received her first loans in 2005 and 2006, and all the repayments were successful.
With this next loan, she plans to buy a grinding mill and a peeling machine, install the machines and a SONEL meter, and pay rent. She is convinced the business will succeed, because she has been doing the business for a very long time. M. promises to use the profits from her loan to educate her children and provide good food and shelter for them. She prefers to receive a loan from GHAPE, because the organization is trustworthy, and the system of repayment is comfortable.
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loan.use: To buy a grinding mill and a peeling machine

loan.name: Nasiba

texts.en: Nasiba A. is 25 years old. She is married and she is a mother of one child. Mrs. A. lives in the B.Gafurov region, but she works in the Khujan local bazaar Panjshanbe. She has been an active client since 2003, and has a good reputation, so she has not had any problems repaying the previous loans. She trades fruit such as bananas, oranges and pineapple. She also sells perfumes. Mrs. A. is requesting a business development loan to import more fruit.

loan.use: To import more fruit

loan.name: Sary

texts.en:
Mrs. Sary K., 44, and her husband, Mr. Bunthoeun Khem, 43, live in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1985 and have five children: one son and four daughters. One daughter is married and lives outside the family home. One daughter is learning beautician skills, their son is a worker in the village, and the other two daughters study at the local school.
Mrs. Sary and her husband have been raising pigs for six years. Besides raising pigs, they also mill rice in front of their house to get extra income. Now, the couple needs to create another business of raising ducks. Therefore, Sary is requesting a loan to run her business of raising ducks.

loan.use: To purchase ducks for raising.

loan.name: Group 03- ng Hi

texts.en:
Loan Group 3 consists of five poor women, all of whom live in Xun Lc Village, in ng Hi Commune, Thanh Ho City. Thanh Ho City is the provincial capital of Thanh Ho province, one of the poorest provinces in Vit Nam. It is located approximately 150 kilometers south of H Ni, the capital of Vit Nam.
Mrs Lin is the lead borrower of the group. She is 47 years old, widowed, and has four children. Her husband was killed in the Vit Nam War (known in Vietnam as the American War). Her eldest two daughters are married, her 18 year old daughter is in the 11th grade, and her 19 year old son has left school but is taking extra lessons prior to sitting his university entrance exams.
As with her previous four loans, all of which have been repaid on time and in full, Mrs Lin will use her share of the loan to buy pork that she will BBQ and sell in her village. A true entrepreneur, she will also buy and raise pigs, chickens and ducks. Mrs Lin will use her profits from the loan to pay her childrens' tuition fees.
The loan will be split equally between all five borrowers. The other borrowers in the group will use their share of the loan for similar purposes:
Mrs. Tm is borrowing 2,442,600 Vietnamese Dong (~ US$143) to buy pork that she will sell in her village and in Thanh Ho City (a six mile bicycle ride from her home).
Both Mrs. Xun and Mrs. Ng Th Vn will use their shares of the loan to purchase fishing nets and other fishing equipment.
Mrs. Lan is borrowing to buy apples, oranges and bananas that she will resell in Thanh Ho City and her Village.

loan.use: To buy pork, chickens, ducks, fruit and fishing equipment

loan.name: Sokun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokun S., 31, and her husband, Mr. Pov Prich, 36, live in a small village across the Mekong River about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1997 and have two children. Their son studies in primary school and their daughter is still young and is at home.
Mrs. Sokun has been selling fish for eight years. She buys them from a fishing lot for resale to the middleman in her village. Her husband has been producing rice wine and raising pigs for three years. The couple want to expand their pig raising business. Therefore, Sokun is requesting a loan to purchase more pigs to raise.

loan.use: To purchase pigs to raise.

loan.name: Ehouloume

texts.en:
Alid means another path always exists for the most poor in Fon, the principal tribal language of Cotonou, Benin. Benin is a small country in West Africa sandwiched between Togo and Nigeria. GDP per capita stands at $1,500 and poverty is endemic to the capital city of Cotonou. Alid operates seven different locations in and around Cotonou to ensure that those who need help can help themselves through small loans.

Ehouloume G. sells drinks in a small stall on the side of a busy road full of motorcycles in Cotonou. Ehouloume sells a large selection of drinks; including soda, beer, liquor, and bottled water for the thirsty inhabitants of the neighborhood. Ehouloume has sold drinks for three years and has one employee, Bridgitte. Ehouloume has some 15 loyal clients who buy large quantities of drinks, in addition to the local passersby in the street.

With her current loan, Ehouloume will stock up on supplies. Ehouloume also has another business selling clothes and shoes at her house. With future loans, she would like to enlarge her home business.

loan.use: Purchase of various drinks

loan.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth O. is 24 years old and is married to a local businessman. They have two children, one of whom is in school. They live in Rongo, Kenya.

Elizabeth owns a shoe store in Rongo, where she sells new shoes. Elizabeth has owned the shop since 2005 and buys the shoes from the nearby town of Kisii.

Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 10,000 Kenya Schillings in order to expand her business by purchasing a larger variety with other types of shoes.

loan.use: To purchase shoes

loan.name: Phanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Phanny S., 42, and her husband, Mr. Sophoin Tep, 52, who live along National Road Number One about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1993 and have three children: one son and two daughters. All of their children attend school.

Phanny has been selling gasoline in the village for over ten years. Her husband has been in the business of renting musical instrument to villagers for ten years as well. They hope that their businesses will be able to allow their children to study to as high a level as possible. Phanny is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to ride to school.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to school

loan.name: Vannak

texts.en:
Mr. Vannak S., 42, and his wife, Mrs. Chanthou Yorn , 41, who live along National Road Number One about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1985 and have five children: four sons and one daughter, all of whom attend school.

Mr. Vannak and his wife have been growing rice for fifteen years. Besides rice farming, he is employed by villagers to plow their rice fields with his tractor, for pay. He has been running this business for five years as well. Now his tractor is broken and he lacks the money to repair it. Therefore, Vannak is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to repair his tractor and to use for their rice farm business.

loan.use: To repair his tractor and to purchase rice seed and fertilizer

loan.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa A. M. is 34 years old and is married with four children. Three of her children are in school in Rongo, Kenya.

Teresa has been selling second hand clothing in Rongo since 2006. She is applying for a loan of 10,000 Kenya Schillings in order to purchase more second hand clothes to increase her inventory.

loan.use: To purchase second hand clothes

loan.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. Ny Y., 35, and her husband, Mr. Hout Sen, 35, who live on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1992 and have two sons who attend school.

Ny has been a silk weaver since she was seventeen years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She also taught her husband to do silk weaving as well. She sells her finished products to the middleman, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Hout has been a carpenter since he was twenty years old, a skill he learned from his father. He produces looms, tables, and cupboards for sale.

Now, Ny is requesting a loan of US$ 350 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loan.use: purchase silk material for weaving.

loan.name: Slamas

texts.en:
Mrs. Slamas H., 49, is a widow with one son who is twenty-eight years old. He assists his mother in selling fish. The family lives along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Slamas has been selling fish for nineteen years. She buys them from fisherman along the Mekong River for re-sale to the middleman, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a boat and an apparatus for fishing.

loan.use: To purchase a boat and an apparatus for fishing

loan.name: Nary

texts.en:
Mrs. Nary T., 46, and her husband, Mr. Ny Tem, 47 who live in a small village along National Road Number Two about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1985 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. The elder son is a photographer and the other children attend school.

Nary has been selling grocery items for fifteen years. She buys them from Takhmao market for re-sale at her home. Her husband has been selling fruit for ten years. He buys the fruit from the market in Phnom Penh for re-sale at Takhmao market. Nary can generate about US$ 4 per day in profit and her husband can earn about US$ 7.50 a day in profit.

Nary is applying for a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a camera for her son for his photography business.

loan.use: To purchase a camera for her son's business

loan.name: Yon

texts.en:
Mrs. Yon Y., 46, and her husband, Mr. Kouk Kem, 44, were married in 1981 and have no children. The family lives along National Road Number 5, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. The main income in the family is from her husbands business.
Mrs. Yon is a housewife, while her husband has been selling cows for ten years. He buys them in a nearby village for resale in his village. Therefore, Yon is requesting a loan of $600, and she will use this loan to help her husband purchase cows for resale.

loan.use: To purchase cows for resale.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: purchase of foodstuffs for re-sale

loan.name: Akossiwa Ahofa

texts.fr: Ne le 10 dcembre 1987 Lom, le capital de Togo, Madame A. Akossiwa Ahofa est une jeune fille entreprenante. Elle est clibataire est elle na pas denfant, donc elle peut utiliser les profits de son entreprise pour subvenir ses besoins et soutenir sa famille. Elle achte les produits cosmtiques au Grand Marche de Lom, et puis elle les revend Ago, un quartier au nord de la ville.
texts.en:
Born on December 10, 1987, in Lom, the capital of Togo, Miss Akossiwa Ahofa A. is an enterprising young girl. She is single and has no children and can therefore use the profits from her business to provide for herself and support her family. She buys cosmetic products at the big market in Lom and sells them in Ago, an area in the northern part of the city.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: to buy cosmetic products

loan.name: Samai

texts.en:
Mrs. Samai B., 29, and her husband, Mr. Van Veng, 25, who live on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 2002 and have two children; one son and one daughter. All of them attend school.
Mrs. Samai has been a silk weaver nearly ten years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a wooden house builder for three years. Samai is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase silk material for weaving, to set up one more loom for her sister to weave silk, and to expand her husbands business.

loan.use: To purchase silk material for weaving and to set up one more loom for her sister.

loan.name: Group 2- Xun Lc

texts.en:
Loan Group 2 consists of five poor women, all of whom live in Xun Lc Village, ng Hai Commune, Thanh Ho City. Thanh Ho City is the provincial capital of Thanh Ho province, one of the poorest provinces in Vietnam. It is located approximately 150 kilometers south of Ha Ni, the capital of Vit Nam.
Mrs. Hng is the lead borrower of the group. She is married and has two children. Her 21-year-old son is studying to become an electrician at H Ni University, and her 18-year-old daughter is in the 12th grade. As with her previous three loans, all of which have been repaid on time and in full, Mrs. Hng will use her share of the loan to buy and raise approximately 200 small animals consisting of pigs, chickens and ducks. Mrs. Hng will use her profits from the loan to pay school and university fees and to provide board and lodging for her son at Hanoi University.
The loan will be split equally between all five borrowers. The other borrowers in the group will use their share of the loan for similar purposes:
Mrs. Tha, a widow, is borrowing 2,442,600 Vietnamese Dong ($143) to buy oranges, apples, bananas and other fruit that she will resell in her village and in Thanh Hoa City (a six-mile bicycle ride from her home).
Mrs. Ti will use her share of the loan to purchase shrimp and cuttlefish that she'll resell in the market. Cuttlefish is a very popular dish in Vietnamese cuisine.
Mrs. T.nh, a widow, will use her share of the proceeds to buy chickens, ducks and fertilizer.
With her share of the proceeds, Mrs. Qun will buy and raise chickens and pigs for resale.

loan.use: Chickens, ducks, pigs, seafood, fruit and fertilizer

loan.name: Sam-Oun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam-oun M., 53, is a widow with four children: one son and three daughters. Her son is a fisherman. One of her daughters is a silk weaver, another one has full-time employment and one more daughter attends school. The family lives on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Sam-oun has been a silk weaver since 1975. She sells her finished products to the middleman, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Now she is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk material for the weaving business.

loan.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loan.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Alid means another path always exists for the most poor in Fon, the principal tribal language of Cotonou, Benin. Benin is a small country in West Africa sandwiched between Togo and Nigeria. GDP per capita stands at $1,500 and poverty is endemic to the capital city of Cotonou. Alid operates in seven different locations in and around Cotonou to ensure that those who need help can help themselves through small loans.

Daniel A. is a part of the Nonvignon group along with his wife, Elizabeth Houindoedji. They live in a small house near the lake with their four children. Eight years ago he left his job as a chief cook, and has since taken up fishing. Daniel fishes with his trusty net, oar, and basket. Daniel sells Sorabi (Beninese liquor) and assorted items along with his fish.

Daniel has been with Kiva for about four years. With his current loan, he will buy nets, fishing rods, and Sorabi.

loan.use: Purchase of nets, fishing rods, and Sorabi liquor

loan.name: John

texts.en:
John A. is 32 years old and is married with four children. Three of the children are in school. John lives in Rongo, Kenya.

John supports his family by making shoes. He has been making shoes for 19 years, starting when he was only 13 years old. John is applying for a loan of 10,000 Kenya Schillings in order to purchase more materials needed for making shoes.

loan.use: To purchase materials for making shoes

loan.name: Vanra

texts.en:
Miss. Vanra C., 26, is single. She lives with her parents and her sibling. The family lives on an island of the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Her mother is a silk weaver.
Miss. Vanra has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk material for her loom and her mothers loom.

loan.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loan.name: Loung

texts.en:
Mr. Loung C., 46, and his wife, Mrs. Mao Kong, 41, live in the suburb of Phnom Penh City. They were married in 1985 and have nine children: five sons and four daughters. One of them was married and lives outside the family home, three children are garment factory workers, two children are tailors, one has full-time employment, and two children attend school.
Mr. Loung has been a tailor for two years, a skill he learned from his neighbor. His wife has been selling vegetables for about five months. Currently, he wants to create another business running a Tuk Tuk (motorbike taxi). Therefore, he is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase one motor taxi to earn more income to support his family.

loan.use: To purchase one motor taxi (Tuk Tuk).

loan.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mrs. Mary T., 31, and her husband, Mr. Vibol Chan, 34, who live in a small village along National Road Number 5 about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1999 and have two sons. One of her sons attends school, and the other son is still young and stays at home.
Mary has been a tailor for three years, a skill she learned from her master. She buys cloth and silk fabric from the market in Phnom Penh for resale at her tailor shop. Her husband has been a motor Remoque (taxi) driver for one year; he carries goods and people from the village to Phnom Penh and from Phnom Penh to the village.
Mary is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase cloth and silk fabric for resale, and also for growing rice.

loan.use: To purchase cloth and silk fabric for resale, and for growing rice.

loan.name: Anonymous
